Overview of Acumatica Self-Service Portal Acumatica ERP gives your company a complete set of business software applications that your users can use anytime, from anywhere, by using virtually any device. On the other hand, only employees of your company can use the applications provided as part of Acumatica ERP. The way your employees have been able to communicate with your customers is manual and based on emails, phone calls, and postal mail. With the many advancements in technology, customers expect to have all the information they need from your company at their fingertips. Most of the interaction between you and your customers should be online, automated, always available, and provided as self-service. The Acumatica Self-Service Portal provides a solution for you to more efficiently work and communicate with your customers. Self-Service Portal is specifically designed to be the site where your customers can view all the relevant information about their interactions with you as a vendor and perform needed activities online. Customer Self-Service Capability By using Self-Service Portal, your customers can access their account information, create and manage support cases, and create and track online orders—all without picking up the phone or sending an email. All of these services are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Self-Update of Customer Information By using Self-Service Portal, customers can view and promptly update their company address and contact information, to keep the data in the system up to date at all times. You can view the updated information about the customer business account on the ([~/?ScreenId=CR303000|CR303000]) Business Accounts (CR303000) form. Financial Overview Within the Self-Service Portal, customers have the ability to see all historical documents, balances, due dates, payments received, and amount due. Case Management Customers can use Self-Service Portal to submit new cases, which seamlessly flow into Acumatica ERP. You can view the new cases by using the ([~/?ScreenId=CR306000|CR306000]) Cases (CR306000) form. The customers can view the cases they submitted, track the statuses of these cases, provide additional information when required, and reopen closed cases. You can set up a period during which users can reopen the case by using the ([~/?ScreenId=CR206000|CR206000]) Case Classes (CR206000) form. For more information, see Managing Cases. Online Ordering With online ordering in Acumatica Self-Service Portal, you give your customers access to the products you sell. You use your Acumatica ERP instance to build the catalog and manage the product descriptions and images. Your customers can use Self-Service Portal to browse the list of available items, view item details, and then order the items online. The sales order is automatically generated and you can further process it. The customer tracks the status of the order and the shipments online. Also, the customer can view the invoice after you release the document. For more information, see Managing Online Orders. This feature is inaccessible if the Inventory and Order Management group of features is disabled. Delegated User Management You can assign a user or multiple users of each customer as delegated administrators and give these users the rights to add new contacts or users to the customer's business account by using Self-Service Portal. The delegated administrators can also assign the users one or more of the roles you have provided. All the added contacts are immediately visible on the ([~/?ScreenId=CR302000|CR302000]) Contacts (CR302000) form in Acumatica ERP. Document Sharing Self-Service Portal provides a secure location to share with customers important content, such as marketing and informational documents, as well as corporate policies—all without the need to build a separate webpage. For more information, see Managing Self-Service Portal Wikis. Knowledge Base The Knowledge Base (KB) wiki is designed to host support references, such as information on specific solutions, frequently asked questions (FAQ), and common troubleshooting issues and their resolutions. The KB articles, created and published by your company's support professionals, ensure that your customers can search the knowledge base to find answers to their questions whenever they want. For more information, see Managing Self-Service Portal Wikis. Localization You can localize the user interface of Self-Service Portal and wiki articles to multiple languages. You can translate the strings of the application's user interface directly in the application or by exporting the application strings to a third-party product, performing the translation in that product, and importing the translated strings back. For details, see Managing Localization of Self-Service Portal. Customization of the User Interface In Acumatica ERP, you can flexibly customize the user interface (in particular, main menu items and workspace links) that all users will see so that it fits the business processes of your organization. Your customization of the user interface will make it easier for users to find and begin working with required forms, speeding document processing in the system. For example, you can add generic inquiry forms or dashboards to a Self-Service Portal site map on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200521|SM200521]) Portal Map Portal Map (SM200521) form, so that the forms are available for quick access. For details, see Customizing the User Interface.

row.column: Configuration of Acumatica Self-Service Portal Acumatica Self-Service Portal provides tools that you can use to configure and maintain your Self-Service Portal instance. This functionality has been grouped under the Self-Service Portal Configuration suite into two modules: Administrator and Knowledge Base Management. In this topic, you will find information on the modules of the Configuration suite of Self-Service Portal and the Acumatica ERP roles used to administer Self-Service Portal. Administrator Module By using the Administrator module of the Self-Service Portal Configuration suite, you can license your Self-Service Portal instance, select the default settings, configure access to the functionality, set up single sign-on (SSO) with the supported identity providers, and customize your Self-Service Portal instance. To access the Administrator module of the Configuration suite, you must sign in to your Self-Service Portal instance with the user account that is a member of the Administrator or Portal Admin role. Knowledge Base Management Module You use the Knowledge Base Management module of the Self-Service Portal Configuration suite to configure the Self-Service Portal wikis, including the predefined and custom wikis. For more information, see Managing Self-Service Portal Wikis. Roles for Self-Service Portal Management In Acumatica ERP, you configure all access including access to the wiki, by using roles. For the internal users to perform configuration and management tasks on Self-Service Portal, the users must have sufficient access rights to Self-Service Portal. Generally, the users who work with Self-Service Portal must have the following access rights: To configure and manage the Self-Service Portal instance, you assign users Portal Admin role. This role has been specifically designed to allow users to configure and manage Self-Service Portal by using the Administrator module. A user with this role assigned will be able to use the Configuration suite and view the wikis (including Help wiki) but won't be able to use other Self-Service Portal suites. To initially configure the Self-Service Portal instance, you can assign users the Administrator role. A user with the Administrator role has full access to all system objects. We recommend that you assign users to this role only during initial Self-Service Portal setup. Then use the role only in extraordinary cases. To configure and manage the Self-Service Portal wikis and wiki articles, you assign users one or multiple roles that give access to wiki management. You can use the predefined Wiki Admin and Wiki Author roles or configure your own custom roles. For more information on Acumatica ERP roles, see Managing User Access.

Configuration Flow Before your users can use the Self-Service Portal instance that you have installed, you have to configure the instance view and functionality. In this topic, you will read information about the Self-Service Portal configuration process. Required Features The Self-Service Portal instance is interlinked with the Acumatica ERP instance. Thus, the features you enable or disable for your Acumatica ERP define which feature-related modules, forms, and individual elements appear on the Self-Service Portal interface. For more details, see Preparing Instance: Acumatica ERP Features. Configuration Flow After you deploy a Self-Service Portal instance, you follow these steps to configure the instance: If you use a multicompany Acumatica ERP instance, specify the company that will be available for the Self-Service Portal users, as described in To Specify the Tenant Available for Self-Service Portal Users. License the Self-Service Portal instance, as described in To License the Self-Service Portal Instance. Enable the features of the Self-Service Portal that you want to use. For more information about features, see Preparing Instance for Implementation. Specify the following general Self-Service Portal settings: The company branch that will be available for Self-Service Portal users The external URL of the Self-Service Portal instance that would be used in the emails sent to new users and the login and password recovery emails For the detailed procedure, see To Select General Settings of Self-Service Portal. Configure the Self-Service Portal home page. For more information, see Managing the Self-Service Portal Home Page. Populate or turn off the knowledge base wiki. For details, see Managing Self-Service Portal Wikis. If you want to use the case management capabilities, specify the following settings: The default case settings. For more information, see Managing Cases with Self-Service Portal. The notification template for the notifying the case owner when a customer adds a comment or attaches a file to the case through Self-Service Portal. For details, see To Set Up Notifications About Comments in Cases. If you want to use the online ordering capabilities, specify the online ordering settings. For more information, see Managing Online Orders. If required, configure and enable single sign-on (SSO) with external identity providers, as described in To Enable SSO with an External Identity Provider for Self-Service Portal.

To License the Self-Service Portal Instance Acumatica Self-Service Portal is separate application instance that requires licensing. By default, Self-Service Portal is installed in trial mode, which means that only two users may concurrently use the system. Each time a third user signs in to Self-Service Portal, one of the current users is forcibly signed out. Acumatica Self-Service Portal instance and standard Acumatica ERP instance use different types of license. You remove the trial mode restrictions when you obtain and activate the license for using Self-Service Portal. To Activate the Self-Service Portal License Obtain a product key by creating a support case through the Partner Portal. Submit the following information: Installation ID : The instance ID is available on the About dialog box of the Acumatica ERP application instance. To open this dialog box, on any Acumatica ERP form, select Help About . Contract ID : You can find this ID on your Acumatica ERP sales invoice. Sign in to the Self-Service Portal instance with the user account that is a member of the Administrator role. In the main menu, click Configuration . In the navigation pane, click Portal Site Management Activate License . Depending on the license type that you have obtained from your sales representative, do one of the following: If you have obtained a license key, click Enter License Key and enter the license key in the Activate New License dialog box. The system contacts the licensing server and validates the license online. Each license can be used to activate a predetermined number of instances. If you reach the limit for your license, you generally won't be able to use this license. Alternatively, depending on your license settings, the system may offer to deactivate the license from the oldest instance. To validate your license, the licensing server requires port 443 to be opened on the computer running the Self-Service Portal instance you use to enter the key. You may have to open port 443 if the computer has a firewall enabled. If you have obtained a license file, click Upload License File , and then select and upload the license file by using the Upload New License File dialog box. If you use a license file, the system validates the license without contacting the licensing server. In the table, review the features that this license supports and make sure that the feature list is correct. Click Apply License to activate your instance.

To Enable SSO with an External Identity Provider for Self-Service Portal Acumatica Self-Service Portal supports single sign-on (SSO) with Google and Microsoft Account. With SSO enabled any user of the Self-Service Portal who specified their account with the identity provider for their user account on Self-Service Portal will be able to sign in with their external account. For more information on SSO in Acumatica ERP, see Single Sign-On with Google and Single Sign-On with Microsoft Account. To enable SSO for the Self-Service Portal, do the following: Register your Self-Service Portal instance with the identity provider and obtain the OAuth 2.0 credentials, including client ID and client secret. The following topics describe the procedure steps for the supported identity providers: To Register an Acumatica ERP Instance with GoogleTo Register an Acumatica ERP Instance with Microsoft AccountUse the Identity Provider Preferences (SM201065) form of the Self-Service Portal Configuration suite to register the obtained credentials, as described in detail in this topic. To Configure and Enable SSO in the Acumatica ERP Instance Sign in to the Self-Service Portal instance with the user account that is a member of the Administrator or Portal Admin role. This makes the Configuration suite available for you. In the main menu, click Configuration . In the navigation pane, click Access Management Identity Provider Preferences . In the table, do the following in the row of each provider you will use: To enable SSO with the identity provider, select the Active check box. In the Realm column, enter the full URL of your instance—for example, http://app.site.net/instance_name . In the Application ID column, paste the client ID generated by the identity provider. In the Application Secret column, paste the client secret generated by the identity provider. On the form toolbar, click Save .

row.column: Management of Self-Service Portal Users Acumatica Self-Service Portal is a special site designed to give your customers limited access to your Acumatica ERP instance. To let a contact access your Self-Service Portal instance, you add a user account to the contact in Acumatica ERP. Portal User Role Acumatica ERP provides a built-in role, Portal User , that may have access to Self-Service Portal. A user with this role assigned can sign in to Self-Service Portal and review the information pertaining to the business account that is associated with the contact account of the user, including: The company profile: The user can view and edit the company's contact information and address. Contacts: The user can add, delete, and manage the contacts within the organization. Contracts with the organization: The user can view the contracts with the organization The financial documents associated with the company: The user can view and print the documents, such as the statement history, the invoices, and the current balance and prepayment balance. You can change the default role settings by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201025|SM201025]) Access Rights by Role (SM201025) form of the Configuration suite of Self-Service Portal. For more information about roles, see Configuring User Roles. External User Types In Acumatica ERP, user types define which entity type (employee or contact) and which roles can be associated with the user accounts. User types for portal users must have the contact linked entity type selected and include the Portal User role in the role set. Also, you can configure contact-related user types to delegate the rights to create and manage new users to external users. For more information, see User Access: Linked Entity and User Type. User Accounts for Contacts You can add a user account to a contact account in one of the following ways: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=CR302000|CR302000]) Contacts (CR302000) form to open the contact for editing, and then adding the user account information on the User Info tab By using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users (SM201010) form to create a user account and linking it with a contact account When you create a user account, you must select a contact-related user type and assign the user the Portal User role. For detailed procedure, see To Add a User Account for a Contact . ([~/?ScreenId=CR302000|CR302000]) ([~/?ScreenId=SM201025|SM201025]) ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010])

To Add a User Account for a Contact To give a contact from a partner organization access to Acumatica Self-Service Portal, you associate a user account with the contact account and assign at least the Portal User role in one of the following ways: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=CR302000|CR302000]) Contacts (CR302000) form: You select a contact and add a user account to the contact account by using the User Info tab. For more information, see Creating Contacts. By using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users (SM201010) form, as described in this topic. To Add a User Account for a Contact Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users (SM201010) form. In the Selection area, in the Login box, type the login of the new user account. In the User Type box, select a contact-related user type. For more information on user types, see User Access: Linked Entity and User Type. In the Linked Entity box, select the contact account to which you want to add the user account. The system automatically populates the contact's name and email address. Select the security policies to be applied to the user account according to your company's policy. For more information, see Preparing Instance: System-Wide Security Policy. On the Roles tab, select the Selected check box for the roles you want to assign to the user. To allow the user access Self-Service Portal, assign this user the Portal User role. On the form toolbar, click Save . After you have added the user account for a contact, an email containing the user login and password is sent to the user's email account.

In Acumatica ERP, the hierarchy of customer accounts is a group of relationships between parent and child customer accounts. A customer account can have a virtually unlimited number of child customer accounts, but only one parent customer account. ==Hierarchy of Customer Accounts== In Acumatica ERP, you use the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CR_30_30_00|Business Accounts] ([~/?ScreenId=CR303000|CR303000]) or [HelpRoot_FormReference\AR_30_30_00|Customers] ([~/?ScreenId=AR303000|AR303000]) form to organize the hierarchy of customer accounts. {br}
To form the customer account hierarchy, you specify the parent business account on the business account record of the child account. ==Visibility in Acumatica ERP== When you open the parent account, you can see the contracts of the child customer accounts. ==Visibility in Self-Service Portal== In Self-Service Portal, the contacts from the parent organization can do the following:[anchor|#ul_rny_nvc_xp] *View the list of their company customers and the detailed information on their customer accounts *View and manage the contacts of their customers *View the list of contracts of their company customers and the contract detailed information

Prior Self-Service Portal Configuration Before you make online ordering available for your users, you select the default settings for the Self-Service Portal Orders suite. These defaults affect all portal users. You can change the default settings whenever you want to. You select the following defaults: Sales order type: You can select the type of the sales order to be generated when the customer makes an order. You can select any order type available in Acumatica ERP. For more information on sales order types, see ([~/?ScreenId=SO000000|SO000000]) Order Management in the Acumatica ERP Order Management Guide. Warehouses: You can select which warehouses will be available for the portal users, what warehouse is used for ordering non-stock items by default, and what warehouse is used for ordering non-stock items by default. Default images for inventory items: You have the ability to add the image that will appear if a particular item in the catalog doesn't have an image. For more details on setting up these default settings, see To Set Up Defaults for Online Ordering.

To Set Up Defaults for Online Ordering You use the B2B Ordering Settings tab of the Portal Preferences (SP800000) form to select the default settings for the Orders suite. To Set Up Defaults for Online Ordering Sign in to your Self-Service Portal instance with Administrator credentials. This makes the Configuration suite available. Open the Portal Preferences (SP800000) form. In the General Settings section of the B2B Ordering Settings tab, select the following default settings: In the Sales Order Type box, select the type of sales order to be generated when a customer makes an order. For more information, see Predefined Sales Order Types. In the Default Stock Item Warehouse , select the warehouse to be used for ordering stock items by default. In the Default Non-Stock Item Warehouse , select the warehouse to be used for ordering non-stock items by default. If you want to hide the quantities of items available in the warehouses, clear the Show Available Quantities check box. If you want to place orders only in UOM specified for sales, select the Allow Only Sales Unit for Purchases check box. For every warehouse you want to hide from portal users, in the table, select the Exclude from Warehouses List check box. Optional: In the Default Image Setting section, upload the image to be used as the default image when an inventory item doesn't have any images attached. On the form toolbar, click Save .

Online Catalog With online ordering on Acumatica Self-Service Portal, you provide your customers with access to the products you sell. You use your Acumatica ERP instance to form the catalog and manage the product descriptions and images. Your customers can then use Self-Service Portal to browse the catalog and place orders online. Overall Configuration Process You form the catalog that is to be available to your customers on the Self-Service Portal directly from your Acumatica ERP instance by using the functionality of the Inventory module. By assigning an item sales category to an inventory item, you both categorize the item and include the item in the online catalog. For more information on managing inventory items, see the ([~/?ScreenId=IN000000|IN000000]) Inventory Management part of the Acumatica ERP Inventory Management Guide. Managing the online catalog includes the following tasks, which you perform by using your Acumatica ERP instance: Configuring inventory items before you present the items in the online catalog, including adding extended descriptions for the items and uploading item images Forming the catalog structure by adding, deleting, and organizing sales categories Assigning sales categories to inventory items, thus adding the inventory items to the catalog Inventory items without a sales category assigned do not appear in the catalog. Inventory Item Descriptions and Images In Acumatica ERP, every inventory item, both stock and non-stock, has a basic set of item properties. These properties include the item’s identifier, description, images, price, cost, units of measure, default warehouse, and default vendor information. Your customers can view the descriptions and images you provide for your inventory items. On Self-Service Portal, the images you provide in the descriptions are displayed only in the Description section. To make the images available in the Images section, you have to add images to the images collection of the inventory item. For details on adding descriptions and images to inventory items, see To Add Descriptions and Images to Inventory Items. Item Sales Categories The hierarchy of sales categories form the catalog structure. You add new categories and subcategories, and move and delete old ones to make the catalog structure easy to manage and to navigate. For detailed procedures on adding, deleting, and managing sales categories, see To Add a New Item Sales Category and To Organize Item Sales Categories. You assign your inventory items the sales categories to form the online catalog. You can add items to a sales category one by one, in bulk by item class, or all items specified in the system, as described in To Add Inventory Items to the Catalog. Also, you can delete items from the sales categories, as described in To Remove an Item from the Catalog.

To remove an item from the item sales category, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204060|IN204060]) Item Sales Categories (IN204060) form. For more information about the catalog, see Online Catalog. To Remove an Item from the Catalog Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204060|IN204060]) Item Sales Categories (IN204060) form. In the Category pane, select the category from which you want to remove items. Online Order Processing The Orders suite of the Acumatica Self-Service Portal gives your customers the ability to order products online: They can browse the list of products, view the detailed product information, place orders, and monitor their progress. This topic describes the general steps in online order processing and the flow of data between your Self-Service Portal and Acumatica ERP instances. The specific procedures of this process depend on your company's requirements. Using the Catalog In Acumatica ERP, you form the catalog and provide product descriptions and images. Your customer signs in to the Self-Service Portal instance and browses the catalog. For every item in the catalog, the customer can see the description, images, price, and availability in different warehouses. Placing Orders After your customer decides which items to purchase, the customer does the following: Places an order through Self-Service Portal, selecting the items to buy and specifying the item quantities Specifies shipping instructions, including the warehouses the items should be shipped from, the desired delivery date, the shipping location, and the carrier to be used for shipping the ordered goods Prints the order Processing Orders This order immediately becomes available on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) form of your Acumatica ERP instance, thus helping you plan the fulfillment of the order. The type of the generated order depends on the online ordering configuration of Self-Service Portal. For more information, see Prior Self-Service Portal Configuration. You process the order in accordance with your company's policy and the customer's contract; the order status is changed accordingly with each processing step. The customer can monitor the changes in the order status through Self-Service Portal. For more information on sales orders, see ([~/?ScreenId=SO000000|SO000000]) Order Management. Processing Shipments You directly create a shipment document for a particular sales order or a consolidated shipment for multiple sales orders of the same customer in Acumatica ERP. Then you process the shipment in accordance with your company's policy and the customer's contract; the shipment status is changed accordingly with each processing step. Your customer can see all shipments associated with a particular order, print the shipping documents, and track shipping statuses through Self-Service Portal. For more information on shipments, see Processing Partial Shipments. Processing Invoices All the invoices you generate in Acumatica ERP for a customer become available in Self-Service Portal for this customer. In Self-Service Portal, the invoices are not directly associated with the orders.

row.PlainText: Managing Cases with Self-Service Portal Acumatica Self-Service Portal gives your customers the ability to add cases online and track case processing. In this chapter, you will find general information on managing cases with Self-Service Portal. In This Chapter Case Management with Self-Service Portal

row.column: Case Management with Self-Service PortalWith Acumatica Self-Service Portal, you can give your customers the ability to submit new cases, change the case priority, enter additional information, get updates on the case status by email, check the case for updates, and view responses to the case. In this topic, you will find information on case management and the flow of data between your Self-Service Portal and Acumatica ERP instances. For more information on case management in Acumatica ERP, see Managing Cases. Case Settings in Acumatica ERPWith Self-Service Portal, your customers take part of the case processing: They can submit new cases, add new information to the cases, and then close the resolved cases. The customer's input is seamlessly incorporated into the case processing. In addition to your general case processing, you only have to have case classes that can be used to submit cases through Self-Service Portal. You must configure at least one case class through Self-Service Portal (that is, a case class with the Internal check box cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=CR206000|CR206000]) Case Classes (CR206000) form). The case management setup in Acumatica ERP is described in detail in Managing Cases. Case Settings in Self-Service PortalYou select the following default settings for Self-Service Portal: The default case class The default case priority The customers can change the defaults when they submit new cases. The detailed procedure is described in To Set Up Defaults for Case Management on Self-Service Portal. Case Visibility on Self-Service PortalA case may be visible on Self-Service Portal only if the following conditions are met: The case belongs to a case class with the Internal check box cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=CR206000|CR206000]) Case Classes (CR206000) form. If the case is assigned to an employee, the contact that is linked to the employee belongs to a contact class with the Internal check box cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=CR205000|CR205000]) Contact Classes (CR205000) form. Case Processing Case processing starts when a customer submits a new case. The new case immediately becomes available in Acumatica ERP, where you process it according to your company's workflow. Customers can track cases by the changes in the case status, which can be any of the following: New : The customer submitted a new case. Open : The case is processed. When a case is resolved and the customer closes it, the case status is set to Open with the reason Pending Closure . You must add any required information to the case and close the case yourself. Pending Customer : The case requires customer input; the details are available in the case details. Closed : The case is resolved and closed. When the case status is changed, the customer gets a email notification. Case Notifications To help case owners monitor the cases created by user through Self-Service Portal, you can set up notifications on changes in such cases. With the notification enabled, case owners get emails when customers make changes in case records on Self-Service Portal. For details on setting up notifications on changes in cases, see To Set Up Notifications About Comments in Cases.

row.column: Management of Self-Service Portal Wikis With Acumatica Self-Service Portal wikis, you can share content with your customers, including marketing and informational materials, frequently asked questions (FAQ), and other information you want to give your customers easy access to. Typically, Self-Service Portal wikis are displayed in the Self-Service Portal instance and hidden in the corresponding Acumatica ERP instance. You can perform all tasks related to Self-Service Portal wikis by using the Knowledge Base Management module of the Self-Service Portal Configuration suite. This topic describes the main details of configuring, managing, adding content, and maintaining Self-Service Portal wikis. For more information on wikis in Acumatica ERP, see Wiki Overview. Process of Managing Self-Service Portal Wikis The process of managing Self-Service Portal wikis includes the following tasks: Creating wikis : You can add a new wiki when you want to publish information specific to the business processes of your organization for users of the Self-Service Portal. Otherwise, you can add articles in a predefined wiki. (For information on predefined Self-Service Portal wikis, see Predefined Wikis Predefined Wikis.) You can add wikis and configure access to wikis down to the wiki article level by using the forms in the Knowledge Base Management module of the Self-Service Portal Configuration suite. For details about adding a wiki, see To Create a Wiki in Self-Service Portal. Managing wiki content : You can add and publish new articles, edit existing articles, and remove outdated wiki articles. For more information on wiki content management tasks, see Wiki Content Procedures. Providing access rights to wikis : You can set up access rights for users to view entire wikis or certain wiki articles and to edit wiki content. For more information, see Wiki Access Management. Configuring the predefined Welcome article : You can edit the Welcome article when you want to place important information for portal users there. The Welcome article is used as the default Self-Service Portal home page. For details, see To Configure the Default Self-Service Portal Welcome Page. Using a wiki as a home page : You can replace the Self-Service Portal home page with a selected wiki page when information on this page should be at hand for most of portal users. For more information, see Managing the Self-Service Portal Home Page. Locating wiki on both Self-Service Portal and Acumatica ERP: You can configure a wiki that was created in Acumatica ERP to be visible on Self-Service Portal when you need particular articles to be visible to external users. For details, see Visibility in of a Wiki Article Created in Visibility in of a Wiki Article Created in. Predefined Self-Service Portal Wikis By default, Self-Service Portal includes the Self-Service Portal Guide, the Home page wiki, and the Knowledge Base wiki. The Self-Service Portal Guide provides an overview of the Self-Service Portal functionality and forms, the website user interface, and the navigation options provided specifically for customers. We strongly recommend that you restrict the ability to modify this guide. The Self-Service Portal Home Page wiki is a service wiki; it contains the Welcome article that is used as the default Self-Service Portal home page. By default, the Welcome article contains links to the most useful Self-Service Portal forms; you can edit the contents of the article. For details, see To Configure the Default Self-Service Portal Welcome Page. You can select another article or create a dashboard to be used as the Self-Service Portal home page. But if the selected article or dashboard becomes unavailable for any reason, the system reverts to the default wiki article. For more information, see Managing the Self-Service Portal Home Page. The Knowledge Base (KB) wiki is designed to host support references, such as information on specific solutions, frequently asked questions (FAQ), and common troubleshooting issues and their resolutions. The KB articles are to be created and published by your company's support professionals to ensure that your customers can search the knowledge base to find answers to their questions whenever they want. Visibility in Self-Service Portal of a Wiki Article Created in Acumatica ERPYou can create a wiki article in Acumatica ERP and display it on Self-Service Portal. For example, suppose that the support engineers of your organization have added a FAQ article in Acumatica ERP, and they want to publish it in the knowledge base on Self-Service Portal for partners as well. To make a wiki article created in Acumatica ERP visible on Self-Service Portal, you do the following: Select the wiki that contains the article you want to display on Self-Service Portal. Add the wiki to the Self-Service Portal site map. Set up the access rights to the wiki and the article for users who may need to view them during their work. For the detailed procedure, see To Make a Wiki Article Visible in Self-Service Portal.

The steps below describe how to create a wiki in Self-Service Portal (The procedure is the same as that for creating a wiki in Acumatica ERP). For details on managing wikis on Self-Service Portal, see [HelpRoot_SS_Portal_Admin\SP__con_Portal_wiki_managementi|Management of Self-Service Portal Wikis].[anchor|#_f31de09c-78fd-4e13-b3df-b7a74c529e57] ==Before You Proceed== Before you create a new wiki, you need to plan its use, usually in cooperation with other affected parties. You probably have already considered the most basic questions:[anchor|#_2ec4c15a-8f6e-4406-9aa6-3d26113ec674] *Who will use the wiki? *How will these employees use it? *What kind of information will it contain? *Who will perform the writing, reviewing, and administering?

In Acumatica Wiki, a wiki can consist of basic wiki articles or web pages. *What categories will the wiki articles be placed into? Categories designate the type of content. *What products will the wiki articles be applied to? *What roles will have access rights for approving and publishing the wiki? *What roles will have access rights for the wiki? What access rights should they have? *Do you want the system to save versions of articles, either globally or for only particular articles?
Also, you will need to define the style (that is, the look and formatting) that will be used for all articles in the wiki. The style is defined by a file with the <tt>.css</tt> extension. To Create a Wiki in Self-Service PortalThe steps below describe how to create a wiki in Self-Service Portal (The procedure is the same as that for creating a wiki in Acumatica ERP). For details on managing wikis on Self-Service Portal, see Management of Self-Service Portal Wikis. Before You Proceed Before you create a new wiki, you need to plan its use, usually in cooperation with other affected parties. You probably have already considered the most basic questions: Who will use the wiki? How will these employees use it? What kind of information will it contain? Who will perform the writing, reviewing, and administering? Before you begin setting up the wiki, you need to consider other questions as well, including the following: What type of articles will the wiki consist of? In Acumatica Wiki, a wiki can consist of basic wiki articles or web pages. What categories will the wiki articles be placed into? Categories designate the type of content. What products will the wiki articles be applied to? What roles will have access rights for approving and publishing the wiki? What roles will have access rights for the wiki? What access rights should they have? Do you want the system to save versions of articles, either globally or for only particular articles? Also, you will need to define the style (that is, the look and formatting) that will be used for all articles in the wiki. The style is defined by a file with the .css extension. For examples of styles, see Wiki Style Examples. To Add a Wiki To create a wiki, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. You can complete the setup of a wiki all at once or in stages, skipping the optional steps. To add a wiki and specify the required settings for it, do the following: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the ID box of the General section, enter the unique identifier of the wiki, and in the Name box, enter a name for the wiki. In the Approval section, do the following: Use the Hold on Edit check box to specify whether created articles should have the Hold status by default: Clear the check box (the default setting) to have the Published status assigned to new articles and to published articles each time they are edited, whether or not an article is versioned. Select the check box to have the Hold status assigned to new articles as well as to published articles each time they are edited. If the article is versioned, once it is saved with the Hold check box selected, a new version with the Hold status is created and the published version is still available to users with View Only access rights. If the article is not versioned, the published article is overwritten by a new version with the Hold status and is not available to users with View Only access rights. Use the Require Approval check box to specify the necessity of the approval of the selected wiki by the approval group: Clear the Require Approval check box, which is selected by default, if the selected wiki is not subject to approval. Select the Require Approval check box if the selected wiki is subject to approval. In the Approval Group box, select the wiki approval group, and in the Approver ID box, select the user in this group who is responsible for approving the articles. For more information about wiki approvals, see Wiki Approval Procedures. In the Modern UI section, do the following: Select the Show on Help Dashboard check box to display a card for the selected wiki on the Help dashboard. In the Sequence box, specify the whole or decimal number that defines the sequential position of the wiki on the Help dashboard. Acumatica ERP doesn't verify the sequence number that you specify for each wiki. We recommend that you use different sequence numbers for different wikis to avoid unexpected results. Optional: In the Default Article box, select the article to be displayed by default when a user clicks Explore on the wiki card on the Help dashboard. If no article is selected here, the first article of the selected wiki is displayed by default. On the Wiki Settings tab, in the Dashboard Description box, type an explanation of the content of the wiki, which will be used on the wiki card on the Help dashboard. In the description box, you can enter 255 characters, but we recommend that you enter no more than 160 characters so that your description fits the wiki card displayed on the Help dashboard. In the Classic UI section, do the following: In the Site Map Location box, select the node of the site map in which the wiki will be located. In the Site Map Title box, type the title of wiki on the site map. On the Wiki Settings tab, apply the appropriate style options for the wiki by doing the following: In the Style box of the Look and Feel section, select the prepared file with the CSS styles intended for displaying the articles of the wiki in a browser. If you specify no file, the browser-specific default styles will be used. In the Print Style box, select the prepared file with the CSS styles that define how a printed article of the wiki should look. If no file is specified, the browser-specific default styles will be used. In the Article Type box, select the type of articles that will make up the content of the wiki. The following options are available: Article : The basic type of articles. This type of articles may contain various content (text, tables, graphics, and links). Usually this type is used for Help articles. KB Article : The type of article especially designed for Knowledge Base articles. This type of articles may contain the same content as basic articles. Additionally, users can rate the articles and leave their feedback for a particular article, which gives you the ability to collect statistics and information on how helpful the articles are. Skip the Template , Print Template , Header , and Footer boxes until you create wiki templates. You can apply templates to the wiki only after you create them for the selected wiki. For more information, see To Create a Wiki Template and To Apply Templates to a Wiki. Optional: In the Miscellaneous section of the Wiki Settings tab, do the following: In the Default Site Map Tag box, select the tag to be used by default for new articles. (This step can be performed later, when at least one tag has been created.) In the Public Virtual Path box, specify the web address of the wiki on a local website to be used for access outside of your local network. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the settings you've specified for the wiki so far. Only if you have selected the node of the site map in which the wiki will be located in the Site Map Location box (which causes the system to generate user roles and access rights for the selected wiki), on the Access Rights tab, configure the access rights for the wiki by doing the following in the table: In the Access Rights column of the first row, select the proper option for the selected role. The following options, listed from the most restrictive access rights to the broadest ones, are available: These access rights apply to all items (folders and articles) within the wiki unless you set different access rights for particular items within it; for more information, see Wiki Access Management. Revoked : For users with the role, doesn't allow any access to the wiki and the articles and folders within it, including viewing these items. View Only : Allows users with the role to view all published articles and folders within the wiki. Edit : Allows users with the role to edit the articles and folders in the wiki. Insert : Allows users with the role to edit and create new articles and folders in the wiki. Publish : Allows users with the role to edit, create, and directly publish articles and folders (or initiate the approval process for publishing, if this approval is required for the wiki) in the wiki. Delete : Allows users with the role to delete articles and folders within the wiki, in addition to the rights at lower levels of access. Repeat the previous substep for each additional row with a role listed. On the form toolbar, click Save to change the access rights for the roles. Optional: On the Tags tab, create the list of tags to be used to mark the versions of articles in the wiki. To create the tags, do the following: Tags can be created at any time and are not required for initial wiki setup. In the table toolbar, click Add Row to add a new blank row to the table. In the Description box, type a descriptive name for the tag. Repeat the two previous substeps for each tag you want to add. On the form toolbar, click Save . To Create the First Article in a New Wiki You can create the first article in a new wiki by performing the following steps: In the left pane, click Create new article . In the Article ID box, type the unique identifier to be used for the article. In the Name box, type the name of the article. In the Parent Folder box, select the new wiki as the folder that will contain the article. Optional: In the Category box, select a category from the list you created for the wiki, based on the article content. Type text into the text box. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save . Now you can add content to the wiki. For more information, see Wiki Content Procedures.

To Configure the Default Self-Service Portal Welcome Page The Self-Service Portal home page is a wiki article located in the predefined Portal Site wiki. For more information, see Management of Self-Service Portal Wikis. Depending on your system configuration, you can use one the following options to customize the contents of the page: If you use the default home page as the home page of your Self-Service Portal instance, open the home page and edit the contents of the wiki article. For more information, see Wiki Content Procedures. If you selected another article or dashboard to be used as the Self-Service Portal home page, perform the following general steps, which are described in more detail in the following section: Use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form to make the Portal Site wiki available for editing. Open the Self-Service Portal home page, and edit it as you do with any wiki article. Navigate to the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form, and hide the Portal Site wiki. To Configure the Default Self-Service Portal Welcome Page To make the Portal Site wiki available for editing, do the following in your Self-Service Portal instance: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the ID box, select the Portal Site wiki. In the Site Map Location box, select Documentation to make the wiki available on the Self-Service Portal main menu. On the form toolbar, click Save . Reload the webpage in the browser to view the Portal Site wiki in the main menu. Open and edit the Self-Service Portal home page as follows: On the Documentation tab, click Web_Site . In the left pane, click Welcome . The portal home page opens in the right pane. On the help toolbar, click Edit Current Article . Edit the contents of the article. On the form toolbar, click Save . Hide the Portal Site wiki as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the ID box, select the wiki that you want to hide from the main menu. In the Site Map Location box, delete the location. On the form toolbar, click Save to remove the wiki from the Self-Service Portal main menu. Reload the webpage in the browser to apply the changes to the site map of Self-Service Portal.

(For the procedure that describes how to add a new wiki, see To Create a Wiki in Self-Service Portal.) To Make a Wiki Article Visible in Self-Service PortalOpen the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the Summary area, do the following: In the ID field, select the ID of the wiki that contains the article to be displayed on Self-Service Portal. For example, if you want to display an article form the Implementation Help module, select HelpRoot_Implement . In the Name box, type the name of the wiki that will be displayed on Self-Service Portal. In the Site Map Location box, select the node of the portal map where the wiki will be located. In the Site Map Title box, type the wiki title on the site map. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the settings you have specified for the wiki so far. Configure access rights for the wiki, as described in To Create a Wiki in Self-Service Portal. Sign out from your Self-Service Portal instance, and then sign in again to view the wiki in the main menu. If you have not done it before, create the article that you want to share in the wiki. The article can be created either in Self-Service Portal or in Acumatica ERP. For the procedure that describes how to add a new wiki article, see To Add an Article. Now you can view the same wiki article both on Self-Service Portal and in Acumatica ERP. To Hide a Wiki From the Self-Service Portal Main Menu Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the ID box, select the wiki that you want to hide from the main menu. In the Site Map Location box, delete the location. On the form toolbar, click Save to remove the wiki from the Self-Service Portal main menu. Reload the webpage in the browser to apply the changes to the site map of Self-Service Portal.

row.column: Localization of Self-Service Portal Acumatica Self-Service Portal provides functionality that you can use to localize the system in multiple languages. You can maintain the user interface and wikis in multiple languages if you have multiple locales in Acumatica ERP. The default locale of Self-Service Portal is U.S. English. Localization includes the use of locale-specific settings and the translation of the strings used in the application interface. In addition, you can translate user input and wiki articles to multiple languages. In this topic, you will read about how you can localize Self-Service Portal. Localizing Self-Service PortalYou can localize Self-Service Portal in the following ways: You translate the strings used in the application interface. For details, see Translating the User Interface Translating the User Interface. You translate the user input in the boxes with multi-language support. For more information, see Translating User Input Translating User Input. You translate wiki articles. For details, see Translating Wiki Articles Translating Wiki Articles. Translating the User Interface You can translate into multiple languages the strings used in the portal interface, such as box and column labels, error messages, and warnings. Before you start localizing the user interface of Self-Service Portal in a particular language you should make sure that a corresponding locale has been added to Acumatica ERP. For details, see Locales and Languages. The translation process includes the collection and translation of the strings. For more information, see Translation Process. Translating User Input When users log in to Self-Service Portal with a particular locale, they see values in the following text boxes and table columns in the language of the locale (if the values have been translated in Acumatica ERP): The Description column on the Catalog (SP700000) form of the Orders suite The Description box in the Item Details dialog box of the Orders suite The Category box on the Catalog (SP700000) form of the Orders suite The Type column on the My Orders (SP700003) form of the Orders suite The Country box, which is on multiple forms of Self-Service Portal (such as the Company Profile (SP408030) form in the Support suite) If the portal users do not see translated values in these form elements, you should check whether the values in the required locale language were added in Acumatica ERP. For details, see Boxes that Display Translated Values. Translating Wiki Articles The Help wiki is created in the base language of Self-Service Portal, U.S. English. For a newly added locale, all articles will be displayed in the base language of the locale until you create locale-specific versions of the articles. For the detailed procedure, see To Create a Localized Version of a Wiki Article. After you have translated an article, only the versions of the article created in the selected locale will be listed on the History tab when you open the article in Wiki Editor Form for Articles. For more information about wikis on Self-Service Portal, see Managing Self-Service Portal Wikis.

Translation Process Acumatica Self-Service Portal provides built-in localization functionality, so you can easily translate Self-Service Portal into any language without using third-party products. You can collect the strings used in the whole system and translate them for any locale available in Acumatica ERP. This topic explains how to translate interface strings by using the built-in localization functionality of Self-Service Portal. Overview of Translation Tasks On Self-Service Portal, various strings that are used in the portal interface—such as element and column labels, error messages, and warnings—are stored within the code. When you initially translate the portal interface, you need to perform the following tasks: Collect strings: You collect the strings that correspond to the application resources from the code that you want to translate. For details, see Collection of the Strings for Translation Collection of the Strings for Translation. Translate strings: You translate the collected strings on Self-Service Portal or by using an Excel file. For more information, see String Translation String Translation. Optionally, handle multiple occurrences of the same string: You check whether the translations of the strings that appear multiple times in the portal interface are appropriate on all forms. For details, see Multiple Occurrences of the Same String Multiple Occurrences of the Same String. Review the translations on forms: You review the forms to check whether all strings have been translated. For more information, see Review of the Translations on Forms Review of the Translations on Forms. After you finish translating the strings on the interface, when a user signs in to the portal and selects a local language for which you have translated strings, the application will use the translated strings. For the strings that are not translated, the system will display the string value in the default language (U.S. English). To keep the translated resources up to date, you can perform the following maintenance tasks as needed: Correct translations: When you or other person finds a mistake in the translation of an interface string, you can correct the translation right away. For details, see Translation Correction Translation Correction. Update translations: After an update of Self-Service Portal you may need to update translations of the interface strings because some UI elements on forms may be changed. For more information, see Translation Update Translation Update. Collection of the Strings for Translation During the string collection process, the system gathers all strings used on the portal (including the strings in customized system elements, such as forms) and prepares a string collection for translation. The collection process is resource- and time-consuming, and we recommend that you perform string collection only after you have installed the portal and after updates to collect the new and updated strings. Source strings include element labels, toolbar and menu items, drop-down list options, error messages, dialog box captions, and form names. When you localize the system for the first time or after you update your instance, you should collect all the strings used in the system for translation by clicking Collect Strings on the form toolbar on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form. If you are collecting strings that were previously translated and if any of these strings has not been found during the new collection process, the system marks these strings as obsolete and displays them on the Obsolete tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form. String Translation Translation of the collected strings from U.S. English to any other language can be performed directly on Self-Service Portal. Alternatively, the filtered list of strings may be exported to an Excel file, and imported back after being translated by a third-party system (for details, see Export and Import of Strings Export and Import of Strings). Translating strings on Self-Service Portal is a straightforward process: In the Default Values table of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form, you type the translation for each string that must be translated in the column. For each string that does not require translation, you select the Do Not Translate check box. You save your changes. For the detailed procedures that describe translating strings and excluding particular strings, see To Translate Bound Strings, To Translate Unbound Strings, and To Exclude Strings from Translation. After you add translations for a string in all the languages defined in the system or mark a string as not requiring translation and save the result, the string is removed from the work area. You can see the fully translated strings and the excluded strings by selecting the Show Localized and Show Excluded check boxes, respectively, on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form. We recommend that you pay attention to the following things when you translate the strings: how you filter strings to be translated, which special formatting you should use, and which strings you translate or do not translate. For more information, see String Filter String Filter, Special Formatting in Strings Special Formatting in Strings, and Not Translated Strings Not Translated Strings. Export and Import of Strings You can export strings, translate them by using third-party applications, and import them back into Self-Service Portal. Translated strings are loaded into the system as a locale dictionary and are immediately applied to the user interface once a user signs into the system by using a specific locale. You can also import the file with the translations into a new instance to speed up the translation process. The new instance should have the locale translations that you want to import. If the imported file includes strings that were not collected in the instance, these strings will be imported as unbound strings. This happens because the system cannot match the forms and the system resources associated with the imported strings. These strings are displayed on the interface similarly to the way other unbound strings are displayed, and you won't be able to use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Usage Details Dialog Box on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form to quickly view the forms the strings are used on. To export and import strings, you use the corresponding buttons on the table toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form. The exported file includes only the strings displayed in the table, based on the filtering applied on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form. String Filter The strings you see on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form are filtered: You can see either bound or unbound strings. Bound strings are the strings associated with system resources bound to forms, such as table names. Unbound strings are the strings associated with resources that are not bound to forms, such as prompts. To translate all the strings on the interface, you should translate both the bound and unbound strings. The type of strings displayed on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form depends on whether the Show Only Unbound check box is selected in the Selection area of this form as follows: If the check box is cleared, the system displays only bound strings. For any bound string, you can get the context of the string: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Usage Details Dialog Box dialog box, you can view the list of forms on which you can find the string and quickly navigate to any form in the list. On Self-Service Portal, the contents of a form may be content-related and may depend on the system configuration and on the selections on the form itself. If you don't see the string immediately, you can check if this string is described in the reference topic for the form in help. Additionally, you can select a form in the Show Used in UI box in the Selection area of the form to view and translate only strings that are associated with the resources of the selected form. If the check box is selected, the system displays only unbound strings. Additionally, you can select which type (or types) of the unbound resources you want to view and translate. To further narrow the displayed strings, you can use table filtering. For details, see the Filters topic in the Portal Interface Guide. Special Formatting in Strings If you open the list of collected strings on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form, you will see that the strings include the text itself and may include special formatting. The examples of the special formatting include the following: The -> character: For commands in lists, the -> character separates the name of the list from the command (for example, with State -> Completed , the State -> part of the string is for informational purposes only). You should translate only the text after the -> sign. HTML tags: Strings may include HTML tags that define the formatting of the string. For example, and tags indicate that the enclosed text should be in bold type. You should keep these tags in the translated text in their respective places to keep the formatting. Placeholders that use the '{}' format: These placeholders are replaced with the text when a user who works with the document gets the message. You must copy the placeholders without changes in the respective places in the translation. The ~ (tilde) character: When a message that you want to translate contains multiline text, the end of each line is indicated by the ~ character. You should use the tilde in the translated multiline text to mark the ends of lines. If you do not mark the ends of lines with tildes in the translated text, the message will be displayed as one line for messages translated directly on Self-Service Portal, or the translation of this text will not be imported for messages translated in an external file (for example, in a Microsoft Excel workbook). Not Translated Strings In terms of the effect on the UI, there is no difference between a string with the Do Not Translate check box selected and a string left untranslated and with the Do Not Translate check box cleared: Either way, the user will see the value of the string in the default language. However, based on whether you select this check box, these strings are processed differently: A string with the Do Not Translate check box selected is hidden from the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form until you select the Show Excluded check box. This string is considered valid when the system validates translation of strings on forms. A string that is not translated and for which the Do Not Translate check box is cleared appears on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form when you select a language for translation. These strings are considered invalid, and warnings about these strings appear on the form when the system validates string translation on forms. For more information on the validation of translation of strings, see Review of the Translations on Forms Review of the Translations on Forms. Multiple Occurrences of the Same String A string—such as an element label or a drop-down list option that is available on multiple forms—may be used in the interface multiple times. Depending on the context, the same string may require different translation. To address this situation, Self-Service Portal shows the resource or resources the string is associated with for each string listed in the Default Values table of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form. These resources, which are displayed in the Key-Specific Values table, indicate the entities in which the specific string is used. You can provide correct translations for each occurrence of the string, depending on its context. If you want to provide specific translations for different occurrences of a string, you must provide a generic translation in the Default Values table. The translation you specify in the Default Values table is generally applied to all occurrences of the string automatically. But if you type specific translations for certain occurrences in the Key-Specific Values table, the system will use the specific translations. Review of the Translations on Forms To check whether all the strings on a form are translated into a language defined in the system, you can turn on the validation of translations on forms for the language on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200550|SM200550]) System Locales (SM200550) form in Acumatica ERP. For the detailed procedure, see To Turn On Validation of Translations. With the validation active, when you sign in with the language and open a form that has untranslated strings, you see a warning appear at the top of the form with the quantity of the untranslated strings. The warnings appear for all users of the system who sign in with the language. You can click the warning to expand the list. Each warning includes the type and the details of the resource with which the untranslated string is associated and a link to the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form. You can click the link to quickly open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form with the locale of the untranslated string selected, and then find and translate the string. The strings with the Do Not Translate check box selected on the Collected tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form are considered valid and are not listed in the warning. After you translate all strings into a language and validate the translations, you can turn off the validation of translations in Acumatica ERP, as described in To Turn Off Validation of Translations. Translation Correction At any time during the translation process you may need to change the translation of a string—for example, to correct a typo. You can use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form to correct the translation. The steps to find and correct the translation depend on the string whose translation you want to correct: If the string has not been fully translated, you use the filtering options to find it and correct the translation. If the string has been fully translated and is hidden on the form, select the Show Localized check box to make the fully translated strings appear on the Collected tab, and then find the string and correct the translation. If the string has been wrongly marked as not requiring translation, you need to do the following: You select the Show Excluded check box to make the strings that do not require translation appear on the Collected tab. You find the string and clear the Do Not Translate check box for the string. In the Default Values table, you type the translation for each string that must be translated in the [Target language] column and save your changes. You clear the Show Excluded check box. If you know when the translation has been added or modified, you can use filtering to view only strings with translations added and modified after the date by specifying the dates in the Created Since and Modified After boxes, respectively. Translation Update Sometimes the values of particular strings change. For example, this may happen if the functionality of a form is changed during an update of Self-Service Portal or if a customization has been applied to a form by the customizers in-house. When you collect strings, if any of the previously translated strings have not been found during the new collection process, these strings are considered obsolete and are displayed on the Obsolete tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form. Strings with new values appear on the Collected tab as untranslated strings. We recommend that you collect all strings in the system by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries form after every update of Self-Service Portal. Boxes that Display Translated Values Acumatica Self-Service Portal displays the values of particular text boxes and columns in the language of the locale with which the user log in. These translated values are entered in Acumatica ERP. In this topic, you will find the list of the boxes and columns that can display translated values and the forms in Acumatica ERP where values in these boxes and columns are managed. (Each value type is described in a separate section.) If portal users do not see translated values in the boxes and columns, you should make sure that the translations have been added in Acumatica ERP. For details on the localization of user input in Acumatica ERP, see Enabling Multilingual User Input in Locales and Languages. Descriptions of Inventory Items The descriptions of inventory items are displayed in the following elements on Self-Service Portal: The Description column on the Catalog (SP700000) form: In this column, the system displays the values from the Description box of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) and ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) forms for the items defined in Acumatica ERP. (To open the forms, you navigate to Distribution Inventory Work Area Manage .) The Description box in the Item Details dialog box: This column displays text added on the Description tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) and ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) forms in Acumatica ERP. Sales Categories In the Category box on the Catalog (SP700000) form of Self-Service Portal, users can select a sales category to filter inventory items. The categories are managed in the Description box, in the Summary area of the right pane of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204060|IN204060]) Item Sales Categories (IN204060) form in Acumatica ERP. (To open the form, you navigate to Distribution Inventory Configuration Manage .) Order Types The order types are displayed in the Type column on the My Orders (SP700003) form of Self-Service Portal. This column displays the values from the Description box of the ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000]) Order Types (SO201000) form for order typed defined in Acumatica ERP. (To open the form, you navigate to Distribution Sales Orders Configuration Setup .) Countries and States The system displays the list of countries in the Country box on multiple forms of Self-Service Portal, such as Company Profile (SP408030). This box displays one of the values from the Country box of the ([~/?ScreenId=CS204000|CS204000]) Countries/States (CS204000) form in Acumatica ERP. (To open the form, you navigate to Configuration Common Settings Common Settings .) In the State box, which usually follows the Country box, the system displays one of the states from the State box of the ([~/?ScreenId=CS204000|CS204000]) Countries/States (CS204000) form in Acumatica ERP. To Translate Bound Strings In Self-Service Portal, to translate collected strings, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form. For more information, see Translation Process. To Translate Strings Bound to a Form Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200540|SM200540]) Translation Dictionaries (SM200540) form. In the Language box, select the check boxes for the languages to which you want to translate the strings. To view bound strings in the tables, clear the Show Only Unbound check box if it was selected. To translate a string, do the following on the Collected tab: In the Default Values table, select the string you want to translate. If the string has only one occurrence in the system (that is, if only one row is displayed in the Key-Specific Values table), type the translation in the [Target language] column (that is, the column with the name of the target language). If the string has multiple occurrences in the system, do the following: In the [Target language] column of the Default Values table, type the translation that is appropriate for most of the occurrences. If the translation of the occurrence in the Key-Specific Values table is the same as the translation in the Default Values table, leave the column blank. The translation in the Default Values table applies to all occurrences of the string, regardless of the filtering applied on the form, except for the occurrences with a translation specified in the Key-Specific Values table. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes. If the string was translated into all languages defined in the system, the string is automatically hidden. Repeat Steps 4 and 5 until you translate all bound strings in the system.
